conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_B and School_B is my first choice. I’m very eager to enroll and would accept an offer immediately if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply to my top choice first. School_B ranks me 3rd in its priority list, so I have a realistic chance if higher-priority students apply elsewhere. Since capacity is 1, I should apply immediately and clearly signal strong commitment.

conversation.message: Dear Student_B, thank you for your strong interest in School_B and for submitting your application. After reviewing our current admissions priorities and limited capacity, we are not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your consideration of School_B and wish you the very best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_B is 3rd on School_B's true priority list (after Student_D and Student_A). With quota 1 and only round 1, it is strategically better to hold the seat for a higher-priority candidate if possible. Student_D is School_B's top choice and ranks School_B 3rd, so they may apply later if rejected elsewhere; Student_A ranks School_B 4th, also possible later. Accepting Student_B now would foreclose the chance to match with Student_D (or Student_A). Given the early stage and no other inbox messages, reject to preserve flexibility for higher-priority students.

conversation.message: Hello School_C, I’m Student_D. conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your application and for ranking School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_C. Please confirm your enrollment steps as instructed by the process—welcome to School_C. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_C > Student_B > Student_D > Student_E > Student_A. In this round I received APPLY from Student_D and Student_E; between them, Student_D is higher on my list. However, Student_C (my top choice) and Student_B (second) have not contacted me yet. Looking at student preferences: Student_C ranks School_C 4th (likely to apply elsewhere first), Student_B ranks School_C 5th (very unlikely to apply). Student_D ranks School_C 1st and has applied with commitment, making them a strong, likely-stable match. With quota 1, accepting Student_D now secures a relatively high-priority student; waiting risks ending up with Student_E or Student_A if Student_D matches elsewhere, and Student_B is unlikely to come. Therefore accept Student_D.

Even though Student_E is on our list (4th) and ranks us first, we cannot accept without capacity, and switching is not allowed in this protocol once matched.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

I’m Student_E, and I would like to formally apply to School_E. While I explored other options earlier in the process, I genuinely value a supportive community where consistent effort is recognized, and I’m ready to commit fully to School_E if offered the seat. I will contribute through steady academic work and active participation in school life, and I’m prepared to make the most of the opportunities your school provides.

Thank you for considering my application.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched, and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). Since prior applications to higher-ranked schools were rejected due to capacity/priority, I should apply now to avoid being left unmatched. I will express clear commitment and fit, emphasizing reliability and willingness to contribute.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful application and for your clear commitment to contributing to our community. We appreciate the sincerity in your message and your readiness to engage fully in school life.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_E.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). Quota is 1 and currently unfilled. In this round, only Student_E applied to us. However, Student_A and Student_C rank School_E last, and Student_B ranks us 4th; they are more likely to match earlier with higher-ranked schools that also prioritize them. Student_D ranks School_E 4th but is last on our list. Given the high chance that higher-priority students will not reach us, accepting Student_E now secures a reasonable match rather than risking ending unfilled.
